1.content:
The movie review app

The movie review app allows users to add movies and reviews for those movies.

This project is the final of the three full stack fluency projects, designed to help you get comfortable building full stack applications.

Follow the steps below to complete the implementation of the movie reviews app.
Nested entities

This project ups the complexity a little by managing two different entities in the database instead of the single entity of each of the previous projects. Please read the article on nested entities before continuing with this project.
The starter repo

Fork and clone the starter repo.

The README for the repo has the basic info to get the application up and running.
The steps at a high-level

    Create SQL statements to create the database. (Most of this step has been done for you today )
    Ensure that the application runs.
    Complete the get_movies() database function.
    Complete the get_movie() database function.
    Write the DBReview database model.
    Complete the get_reviews() database function.
    Complete the create_review() database function.
    Write the addReview JavaScript function.
    STRETCH GOAL: Restrict ratings to 1-5.

NOTES:

    All tasks for you to complete are marked in the code with "TODO" and some instructions for what you are supposed to do. If you think you are done, search your project for the term "TODO" to make sure.
    All the HTML and CSS files are complete. You do not need to alter any of the HTML or CSS files.
    Use the books project and previous full-stack fluency projects as a reference. Try to remember, type out some code from memory, and see if it works, but don't beat yourself up for too long. Go to the reference project and see how things are done there.

The steps in detail
1) Create the database table and sample data

The SQL statements to create the movie and review tables, as well as populate them with some sample data that has been provided in the file data/movies.sql.

You do still need to create a database and run the statements to populate it.
Populate your database

Log in to your database server's psql shell and do the following:

    Create a database called movies.
    Make movies the current database.
    Populate your database using one of the following methods:
        Copy and paste your SQL statements directly into the psql shell.
        Run \i data/movies.sql in the psql shell.

Note: If \i data/movies.sql above doesn't work, you probably have an old postgres docker container. Use the docker commands recommended in the project's README file to get a fresh start.
Make sure you have data

Run a SELECT statement like SELECT * FROM movie to make sure the table is there and has data in it.
2) Ensure the application runs

Start your FastAPI server and make sure it runs without errors. It won't do much, but there shouldn't be errors.

Run your server:

fastapi dev main.py

Check out the following links in your web browser and make sure they work:

http://localhost:8000/index.html

http://localhost:8000/docs

You shouldn't see any errors in your terminal where you started FastAPI, or any JavaScript errors in your web browser console. If so, please get them fixed-up before proceeding.
3) Complete the get_movies() database function
The database function

In db.py, there is a single line that you need to complete in get_movies() to finish it off. Please see the TODO there to complete this step.
Test it out

FastAPI Swagger UI: http://localhost:8000/docs

The HTML/JavaScript UI: http://localhost:8000/index.html

You should see all of the movies.
4) Complete the get_movie() database function
The database function

In db.py, implement the get_movie() function. The comments in the TODO will provide all the necessary details.
Test it out

FastAPI Swagger UI: http://localhost:8000/docs

The HTML/JavaScript UI: http://localhost:8000/movie-detail.html?id=1

You should see movie details on the page.
5) Write the DBReview database model
The DB model

In db_models.py, you will find that the model DBMovie has already been implemented, but DBReview has not. Please complete the implementation of the DBReview class.

Please refer to data/movies.sql for a reference of the review database table.

Here is a reference for the ForeignKey function that is used in SQLAlchemy.
Test it out

There's not much of a way to test this directly, but the next step will!
6) Complete the get_reviews() database function
The database function

In db.py, implement the get_reviews() function. The comments in the TODO will provide all the necessary details.
Test it out

FastAPI Swagger UI: http://localhost:8000/docs

The HTML/JavaScript UI: http://localhost:8000/movie-detail.html?id=1

You should be able to see all of the reviews for a movie.
7) Complete the create_review() database function
The database function

In db.py, implement the create_review() function. The comments in the TODO will provide all the necessary details.
Test it out

FastAPI Swagger UI: http://localhost:8000/docs

You should be able to add a movie review and then see it in the list of reviews for a given movie.
8) Write the addReview JavaScript function
The JavaScript code

In static/add-review.js, follow the instructions in the TODO to implement the addReview() function.

The HTML/JavaScript UI: http://localhost:8000/add-review.html

You should be able to add a review and then see it on the movie details page.
9) STRETCH GOAL: Restrict ratings to 1-5

Currently when you create a review, it allows you to enter any number for the rating. Please update the UI so that only values from 1 to 5 are allowed.

In the JavaScript function you wrote above, add some code to:

    Test the value of rating
    If it is between 1 and 5: Continue on
    if it is less than 1 or greater than 5 (or not a number): Please use a JavaScript alert box to notify the user of the error and then abort the attempt to create a review

1.content:
FSF Project: The blog app

For today's project, the final project of the Full-Stack Fluency unit, you will complete the implementation of a simple blog application. The team that was working on it before created pages and logic for the "show all posts" and "post details" pages but didn't get around to working on the "create new post" workflow at all, so that will be your work for the day.

There are more details below, but in short, you will need to create all of the parts, end to end, for the "create new post" workflow:

    A FastAPI endpoint and database function for creating a new post
    An HTML page with a "new post" form
    JavaScript to submit the HTML form to the FastAPI endpoint

There's some work to do, but given all the practice you've had, it should be no problem. Let's get at it!
The starter repo

Fork and clone the starter repo.

The README for the repo has the basic info to get the application up and running.
The steps at a high-level

    In data/blog.sql, create SQL statements to create the "post" table and load some test data into it.
    In schemas.py, you'll see there is an "out" model defined, but nothing else. Please create a "create" model.
    In main.py, create a route to handle POST requests to /api/posts. The TODO in the file has the details.
    In db.py, implement the create_post() function. The TODO in the file has the details.
    In static/post-create.html, create the HTML for the "Create new post" page.
    In static/post-create.js, write the JavaScript necessary to create a new post when the button is clicked.

Notes:

    All tasks for you to complete are marked in the code with "TODO" and some instructions for what you are supposed to do. If you think you are done, search your project for the term "TODO" to make sure.
    Use the books project and previous full-stack fluency projects as a reference. Try to remember, type out some code from memory, and see if it works, but don't beat yourself up for too long. Go to the reference project and see how things are done there.

Grading

To pass this assignment, the following must all be true of your completed project:

    The SQL statements in data/blog.sql will properly create the post table and populate it with some sample data.
    There is a FastAPI route for a POST request to /api/posts that will create a new post in the post database table.
    The file static/post-create.html contains a form with the fields for a blog post.
    The file static/post-create.js contains JavaScript code that processes the form above and makes a request to the FastAPI endpoint above to create a new blog post.

The steps in detail
1) Create SQL create and insert statements
Create the post table

Study the following entity relationship diagram (ERD) and then, in data/blog.sql, write a CREATE TABLE statement for the post table.

Post table
Create some sample data

Also, in data/blog.sql write one or more INSERT statements to add some sample blog posts to your post table.
Populate your database

Log in to your database server's psql shell and do the following:

    Create a database called blog.
    Make blog the current database.
    Populate your database using one of the following methods:
        Copy and paste your SQL statements directly into the psql shell.
        Run \i data/blog.sql in the psql shell.

Note: If \i data/blog.sql above doesn't work, you probably have an old postgres docker container. Use the docker commands recommended in the project's README file to get a fresh start.
Test it out

Run a SELECT statement like SELECT * FROM post to make sure the table is there and has data in it.
2) Ensure the application runs

Start your FastAPI server and make sure it runs without errors. It won't do much, but there shouldn't be errors.

Run your server:

fastapi dev main.py

Check out the following links in your web browser and make sure they work:

http://localhost:8000/posts.html

http://localhost:8000/docs

You shouldn't see any errors in your terminal where you started FastAPI, or any JavaScript errors in your web browser console. If so, please get them fixed-up before proceeding.
3) Create a Pydantic schema

In schemas.py, you'll see there is an "out" model defined, but nothing else. Please create a model to use when creating a new post.
4) Create a FastAPI route

In main.py, follow the directions in the TODO to create a new route for creating a new blog post.
Test it out

    Use the FastAPI Swagger UI to test your new endpoint. http://localhost:8000/docs
    You will see the route, but will get a 500 error if you try to execute it. This is ok, for now.

5) Implement the database function

In db.py, follow the directions in the TODO to implement the database function that will create a new blog post in the database.
Test it out

    Use the FastAPI Swagger UI to test your new endpoint. http://localhost:8000/docs
    Now, you should see all the sample posts that you inserted into the database.

6) Write an HTML page with a form

In static/post-create.html, follow the directions in the TODO to create an HTML page and form for creating a new blog post. The page should look something like this:

New blog post page
Test it out

    Click on the "Create New Post" menu item or go directly to the URL http://localhost:8000/post-create.html.
    You should see your form. If you click on the submit button, it will appear to submit, but a post will not be created in the database

7) Write the JavaScript to submit the above form

In static/post-create.js, follow the directions in the TODO to write JavaScript code that will submit the data in the form to your FastAPI endpoint to create a new blog post in the database.
Test it out

    Click on the "Create New Post" menu item or go directly to the URL http://localhost:8000/post-create.html.
    Submitting the form should now create a new blog post in the database.

Congratulations!!!

If you made it this far, you are done! Go get some fresh air; you deserve it.

# Changelog

## 2.0.8

- Update Bedrock default Sonnet model to `global.anthropic.claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929-v1:0`
- IDE: Add drag-and-drop support for files and folders in chat
- /context: Fix counting for thinking blocks
- Improve message rendering for users with light themes on dark terminals
- Remove deprecated .claude.json allowedTools, ignorePatterns, env, and todoFeatureEnabled config options (instead, configure these in your settings.json)

## 2.0.5

- IDE: Fix IME unintended message submission with Enter and Tab
- IDE: Add "Open in Terminal" link in login screen
- Fix unhandled OAuth expiration 401 API errors
- SDK: Added SDKUserMessageReplay.isReplay to prevent duplicate messages

## 2.0.1

- Skip Sonnet 4.5 default model setting change for Bedrock and Vertex
- Various bug fixes and presentation improvements

## 2.0.0

- New native VS Code extension
- Fresh coat of paint throughout the whole app
- /rewind a conversation to undo code changes
- /usage command to see plan limits
- Tab to toggle thinking (sticky across sessions)
- Ctrl-R to search history
- Unshipped claude config command
- Hooks: Reduced PostToolUse 'tool_use' ids were found without 'tool_result' blocks errors
- SDK: The Claude Code SDK is now the Claude Agent SDK
- Add subagents dynamically with `--agents` flag

## 1.0.126

- Enable /context command for Bedrock and Vertex
- Add mTLS support for HTTP-based OpenTelemetry exporters

## 1.0.124

- Set `CLAUDE_BASH_NO_LOGIN` environment variable to 1 or true to to skip login shell for BashTool
- Fix Bedrock and Vertex environment variables evaluating all strings as truthy
- No longer inform Claude of the list of allowed tools when permission is denied
- Fixed security vulnerability in Bash tool permission checks
- Improved VSCode extension performance for large files

## 1.0.123

- Bash permission rules now support output redirections when matching (e.g., `Bash(python:*)` matches `python script.py > output.txt`)

- Enhanced BashTool environment snapshot logging
- Fixed a bug where resuming a conversation in headless mode would sometimes enable thinking unnecessarily
- Migrated --debug logging to a file, to enable easy tailing & filtering

## 1.0.120

- Fix input lag during typing, especially noticeable with large prompts
- Improved VSCode extension command registry and sessions dialog user experience
- Enhanced sessions dialog responsiveness and visual feedback
- Fixed IDE compatibility issue by removing worktree support check
- Fixed security vulnerability where Bash tool permission checks could be bypassed using prefix matching

## 1.0.119

- Fix Windows issue where process visually freezes on entering interactive mode
- Support dynamic headers for MCP servers via headersHelper configuration
- Fix thinking mode not working in headless sessions
- Fix slash commands now properly update allowed tools instead of replacing them

## 1.0.117
